problem_statement: Find the shortest distance between two skew lines $L_1: \vec{r} = \vec{a} + s\vec{b}$ and $L_2: \vec{r} = \vec{c} + t\vec{d}$, where $\vec{b}$ and $\vec{d}$ are direction vectors of $L_1$ and $L_2$ respectively.
overview: The shortest distance between skew lines is the length of the perpendicular segment between them. This is obtained by projecting $\overrightarrow{AC}$ (the vector joining a point $A$ on $L_1$ to a point $C$ on $L_2$) onto the normal vector $\vec{b} \times \vec{d}$, which is perpendicular to both $\vec{b}$ and $\vec{d}$.

step_details.explanation: Direction of the common perpendicular is given by the cross product of the direction vectors.
Normalize $\vec{b} \times \vec{d}$ to get the unit vector along the common perpendicular.
Take $\overrightarrow{AC} = (\vec{c} - \vec{a})$, where $A$ lies on $L_1$ and $C$ lies on $L_2$.
The shortest distance is the absolute value of the projection of $\overrightarrow{AC}$ on the common perpendicular $\vec{SD}$.
Simplify the formula for shortest distance between two skew lines.
